anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thereafter referred three questions under s. 66 l  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: We have in a recent case in Kettlewell Dullen Co. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta  1  made a survey of the important cases which have arisen before the Courts in the United Kingdom and in India about the principles which govern the determination of the nature of compensation received on the termination of an agency.

anchor.surface_text: No part of the companypensation may be attributed to loss of goodwill suffered by the appellant. It is true that the agency had continued in the hands of the predecessors of the appellant and thereafter with the appellant for upwards of sixty years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence or material raised before authorities on goodwill value or negotiations; no reference in correspondence; not investigated.

holdings.text: There is no evidence that compensation was paid to the appellant as consideration for giving the undertaking not to carry on a competitive business.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no evidence that compensation was paid to the appellant as consideration for giving the undertaking not to carry on a competitive business, or as compensation for loss of goodwill. In the letter dated March 11, 1947, it was expressly recited that as a condition

holdings.reasoning_summary: No formal undertaking given or accepted; condition ignored by parties in payments over three years without insisting on agreement; no enforcement or investigation.

holdings.text: we agree with the High Court that what was received by the appellant was income and not capital.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the circumstances of the present case in the light of that principle, we agree with the High Court that what was received by the appellant was income and not capital. Compensation received by the appellant for cancellation of the agency which was terminable at will,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied agency termination test: payment computed on basis of lost commission/profits; normal business incident without impairing trading structure or source of income.

holdings.text: There is not even a suggestion, that by the determination of the agency held by the appellant in explosives from the principal company, the trading structure of the assessees business was impaired.

anchor.surface_text: There is not even a suggestion, that by the determination of the agency held by the appellant in explosives from the principal company, the trading structure of the assessees business was impaired. It is manifest that the agencies of the companies conducted by the appellant must have been obtained at different times.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant had diverse agencies across many lines; loss of one terminable agency did not impair overall structure; staff largely principal-funded and reabsorbed.

holdings.text: the acquisition of agencies was in the normal course of business and determination of individual agencies, a normal incident, not affecting or impairing the trading structure of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It may reasonably be held, having regard to the vast array of business done by the appellant as agents, that the acquisition of agencies was in the normal course of business and determination of individual agencies, a normal incident, not affecting or impairing the trading structure of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant conducted business in multiple lines including numerous agencies; agencies obtained/cancelled variably; compensation adjusted lost profits, leaving business free to continue.

holdings.text: the judgment of the Judicial Committee in the Commissioner of Income-tax v. Shaw Wallace and Co. was not intended to, and did not lay down that in every case, cancellation of an agency resulted in loss of a source of revenue or that amounts paid to compensate for loss of agency must be regarded as capital loss.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinguished: no immutable rule for all agency terminations; depends on facts whether impairs structure or normal incident.

holdings.text: cancellation of the contract of agency did not affect the profit-making structure of the appellant, nor did it involve a loss of an enduring trading asset; it merely deprived the appellant of a trading avenue [...] The compensation paid, therefore, did not represent the price paid for loss of a capital asset.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes application: no structural impairment or enduring loss; mere loss of one avenue replaceable in ordinary course.

precedents.citation: Kettlewell Dullen Co. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: Kettlewell Dullen Co. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1 made a survey of the important cases which have arisen before the Courts in the United Kingdom and in India about the prin-

precedents.case_name: Kettlewell Bullen & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: principles which govern the determination of the nature of compensation received on the termination of an agency
precedents.cited_holding: Where on a consideration of the circumstances, payment is made to compensate a person for cancellation of a contract which does not affect the trading structure of his business, not deprive him of what in substance is his source of income, termination of the contract being a normal incident of the business, and such cancellation leaves him free to carry on his trade freed from the contract terminated the receipt is revenue where by the cancellation of an agency the trading structure of the assessee is impaired, or such cancellation results in loss of what may be regarded as the source of the assessees income, the payment made to compensate for cancellation of the agency agreement is normally a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: In the judgment in Kettlewall Bullen and Co. case we have explained that the judgment of the Judicial Committee in the Commissioner of Income-tax v. Shaw Wallace and Co. 1964 8.S.C.R. 93.

precedents.cited_proposition: explanation of prior precedents including Shaw Wallace

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the Judicial Committee in the Commissioner of Income-tax v. Shaw Wallace and Co. 1964 8.S.C.R. 93. Wallace and Co. was not intended to, and did not lay down that in every case, cancellation of an agency resulted in loss of a source of revenue or that amounts paid to compensate for loss of agency must be regarded as capital loss.
